Q&A
Q: How long does it take to measure?
A: About 45 seconds or less.
Q: What is the best time to take the test?
A: Early in the morning or any time you feel relaxed and stress-free.
Q: What is the difference between measuring my blood pressure at home and at a specialized medical clinic?
A: Blood pressure readings taken at home are more accurate because they better reflect your daily life. When measured in a clinical or medical setting, readings may be elevated. This is known as White Coat Hypertension and may be caused by anxiety or stress.
Q: Should I put the cuff on my left or right wrist? What is the difference?
A: Either wrist can be used during the test, but the same wrist should be used when comparing results. The left wrist is closer to the heart, so testing on the left wrist may give more accurate results.
Tips:
1. Take your reading at the same time each day.
2. Avoid exercising, eating, smoking, bathing, and drinking alcohol or caffeinated beverages for 30 minutes prior. Ideally, rest 15 minutes before you begin.
3. Sit in a chair with your feet flat on the floor. Rest your arm on a table with your palm facing upward.
4. Avoid unnecessary movements while taking your BP (includes talking).
